author: sky.cactus
content: It is more than I don't want someone to have the power to censor than it is that I don't want to be the censor.  While technically you are correct that editors do have some censorship powers, it is massively constrained for technical standards because the rules for validity are so clear cut.  Informational EIPs necessarily require that power to be greatly expanded.

author: sky.cactus
content: If given the power to censor, I will try to censor a *lot* because 95% of what comes through the EIP process is rubbish IMO.
